titleStmt.title: Mechanical performance of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) refractory high entropy alloys: Perspective from experiments and first principles calculations

analytic.title: Mechanical performance of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) refractory high entropy alloys: Perspective from experiments and first principles calculations

biblStruct.note: Received 3 February 2021 Received in revised form 24 March 2021 Accepted 26 March 2021

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: High entropy alloys First-principles calculations Phase structure Microstructure Mechanical properties

div.p: NbMoTaW refractory high entropy alloy (RHEA) possesses superior high temperature mechanical strength while the very low plastic strain at room temperature limits its practical applications. In present work, the method of adjusting composition was employed to improve the mechanical properties of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys especially the plasticity at room temperature by the combination of experiments and first-principles calculations. Phase composition of the (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys identified using experiments and theoretical prediction were all single-phase solid solution. Microstructure and elements distribution of the alloys were characterized by SEM and EDS. All the as-casted alloys had dendrite structures and the grain size firstly increased (x < 0.15) and then decreased (x > 0.15) with the increase of Mo content. The compressive properties and the analysis of fracture surface demonstrated that strength and ductility of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys were obviously enhanced with the decrease of Mo content. NbTaW MEA had the maximum mechanical strength (1460 MPa) and ductility (16.2%) in the designed alloys. Both the mechanical strength and plasticity at room temperature were greatly improved compared with that of NbMoTaW RHEA. The experimental results well agreed with that of first-principles calculations. The elastic anisotropy and microhardness of these alloys were also predicted. The orders of elastic anisotropy were (NbTaW) 0.75 Mo 0.25 < (NbTaW) 0.85 Mo 0.15 < (NbTaW) 0.95 Mo 0.05 < NbTaW. The hardness of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys were increased with increasing of Mo content. Optimizing composition was demonstrated to be an effective method to improve the mechanical properties of NbMoTaW refractory high entropy alloy.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Compared with conventional Fe-, Al-Ti-and Ni-based alloys, high entropy alloys (HEAs) have higher entropy of mixing and form single-phase BCC, FCC or HCP solid solutions with equiatomic or near equiatomic multi-component elements [1,2]. These distinguished "collective multi-principal characteristics" enable HEAs to possess high strength, high hardness, high wear resistance, excellent high temperature oxidation resistance, corrosion resistance and superior thermal stability [3][4][5][6][7][8][9], which has widespread potential engineering applications. Nowadays, with the development of advanced technologies, the conventional alloys become insufficient to satisfy the harsh working conditions and service lifetimes at elevated temperatures. As the candidate for the next generation of high-temperature structure materials, refractory high entropy alloys (RHEAs) or refractory medium entropy alloys (MEHs) have received the increasing recognition and attention due to its prominent high temperature resistance, high melting points (> 2000 °C) and high strength at elevated temperatures [10][11][12][13]. Being the firstly reported RHEA completely consisted of refractory elements, NbMoTaW alloy possesses excellent high temperature performance due to its high melting point and high entropy effect. For instance, it maintained high strength (405 MPa) at 1600 °C and kept a stable single-phase BCC solid solution at 1400 °C [14,15], which has great potential as the new structure material for high temperature applications. However, NbMoTaW RHEA exhibited the behavior of brittle fracture and its ductility at room temperature was poor. This seriously limits its further engineering application. In order to keep the thermal endurance of NbMoTaW RHEA for high temperature applications, the following factors must be taken into consideration in improving its performance. On one hand, keep its high melting point. In other words, the elements with low melting points are unsuitable to be introduced during the alloy design. On the other hand, its room temperature ductility as well as strength should be enhanced on the premise of the alloy's high melting point. Among the alloy's constituent elements Nb, Mo, Ta and W, Mo has the lower melting point and relatively more poor ductility. Some investigations also show that Mo element leads to the embrittlement of alloys [16,17]. The content of Mo element may play a significant role in improving the mechanical properties of NbMoTaW RHEA. In general, adjusting composition is an effective and common method to improve properties of alloys. For instance, Chen [18] et al. balanced the strength and ductility by composition design of high entropy alloys using the valence electron concentration. Duan [19] et al. optimized the electromagnetic properties of FeCoNiAlCr x alloy by composition adjustment. However, there are no published information about the influence of Mo element on the mechanical properties of NbMoTaW RHEA. Whether the mechanical performance, especially the ductility at room temperature, can be improved by adjusting of Mo element is still unclear.

In the work, the influence of Mo content on mechanical properties of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys was investigated from the perspective of combining first-principles calculations and experiments. For nominal composition of these samples, the concentration of Nb, Ta and W was equi-atomic in the models calculations and experiments. Firstly, experimental and calculated XRD patterns were employed to determine the phase structure. After the reasonability of calculated parameters was verified, both cohesive energy and empirical formula were used to identify the phase structure again. The Mo content dependence of both lattice constant and density were also predicted and analyzed. Secondly, the microstructure and composition of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys were characterized and analyzed. Thirdly, the compressive mechanical properties of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys were experimentally measured and the fracture morphologies were further analyzed. Finally, the elastic properties, microhardness and the predicted brittleness/ductility of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys were systematically calculated to explain the experimental results.

div.head: Experiments
div.p: (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys, marked as Mo 0 , Mo 5 , Mo 15 and Mo 25 , respectively, were prepared by arc melting method. Different proportion of Nb, Mo, Ta and W elements with a purity more than 99.9 wt% were mixed and then melted. For nominal composition of these samples, the concentration of Nb, Ta and W was equi-atomic, and the concentration of four alloys was shown in Table 1. The melting was carried out in the protect environment of high purity argon. All the samples were melted at least 5 times to acquire alloys ingots of uniform compositions. After melting, all the samples were cut into many slices and cylinders using wire electrical-discharge machining. The structure of samples were characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Cu Kα radiation, Rigaku D/Max 2550VB-) with the speed of 5°/min from 2θ = 20° to 90°. Microhardness of samples was measured by Vickers hardness tester (100 g, 15 s). Engineering compression stress-strain curves were obtained using universal testing machine with the speed of 1 mm/ min. The size of compressive samples was Ф5 × 8 mm. The micromorphology of samples were characterized and analyzed by Scanning Electron Microscopy with Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (SEM, EDS, Phenom-World BV, Netherlands).

div.head: Computational methods
div.p: For all the calculations of four alloys in present work, the crystal models of each alloy with BCC, FCC and HCP crystal structure were built by virtual crystal approximate method (VCA). The mole fraction of Nb, Mo, Ta and W used in the models calculations of three crystal structure was set as the same as nominal composition. As one of the most representative of first-principles calculations methods based on density functional theory (DFT) [20], VCA method is an effective and suitable method to predict and simulate the properties of solidsolution alloys composed of neighbouring elements with similar chemical properties [21]. HEAs are considered as long-range disordered alloy system where atoms occupy sites randomly. In the concept of VCA method, a "virtual" atom where all elements distribute in proportion was used to replace the actual metallic atom. Although VCA method is overly simplified solid solutions, some results shown that it is feasible and effective in investigating RHEAs [21][22][23][24].

In (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys, four principal elements in the periodic table are adjacent and VCA method is well suitable for this alloys system. Therefore, the BCC, FCC and HCP crystal structure of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys were built by VCA. The first-principles calculations were performed in CASTEP code [25] based on density functional theory (DFT). The electronic exchange-correlation terms were described using Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) [26] and Perdew Burke Ernzerhof (PBE) of functional [27]. The electron and ionic interaction was described using norm conserving pseudopotential [28]. The BFGS algorithm was selected for geometry optimization. The important parameters of cut energy and k-point were set as 450 eV and 8 × 8 × 8 for NbTaW, (NbTaW) 0.95 Mo 0.05 , (NbTaW) 0.85 Mo 0.15 and (NbTaW) 0.75 Mo 0.25 alloys by convergence testing, respectively. The convergence tolerances of energy, maximum forces, maximum stress and maximum displacement were 1 × 10 -5 eV/atom, 0.03 eV/ Å, 0.05 GPa and 0.001 Å, respectively. For the calculation of theoretical XRD patterns of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys, it was performed by Powder Diffraction module in Materials Studio with the speed of 5 °/min from 2θ = 20° to 90°. The parameters of Pseudo-Voigt function, Debye-Scherrer geometry, X-ray, and Copper source were selected for calculation.

The reasonability of selected models, method and calculated parameters were verified. The lattice constant and density of (NbTaW) 0.75 Mo 0.25 RHEA were calculated to be 3.195 Å and 14.099 g/ cm 3 , respectively. The data were well consistent with the experimental results (3.213 Å and 13.75 g/cm 3 ) [14], which demonstrating the above parameters were reasonable. The next properties calculated by VCA were feasible.

div.head: Elastic constants and polycrystalline elastic modulus
div.p: Elastic constants (C 11 , C 12 , C 44 ) are positively correlated with the polycrystalline elastic modulus containing bulk modulus (B), shear

div.head: Table 1
div.p: The concentration of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys.

div.head: Alloys
div.p: Mole fraction (%) modulus (G), Yong's modulus (E) and Poisson's ratio (ν). They play a key role in determining the mechanical properties of materials. In present work, the elastic properties were calculated by stress-strain method [29]. For the cubic crystal, the polycrystalline elastic modulus (B, G, E, ν) derived from single crystal elastic constants (C 11 , C 12 , C 44 ) were estimated by the Voigt-Reuss-Hill (VRH) approximate methods [30]. They can be described as the following equations:
div.formula: = + G C C C C C C 5( ) 43
div.p: In the above formulas, V and R refer to the value acquired by Voigt and Reuss methods, respectively. Commonly, the Voigt method overestimates the elastic modulus, whereas the Reuss method underestimates the elastic modulus. The Hill method is considered to be the average value of Voigt and Reuss methods.

Besides, the values of elastic constants were used to determine the mechanical stability of crystal structure, the elastic anisotropy ratio (A VR ) and the bonding characteristics of alloy system. For the cubic crystal structure, it can be considered to be elastic stability if these elastic constants are fit to the mechanical stability criteria [31], described as Eq. (7).

Anisotropy of elasticity has an important influence on material's microcracks and deformation. In this work, anisotropy of elasticity of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys were predicted by Eq. ( 8). The referenced value of = A 0

div.head: VR
div.p: shows the elastic isotropy and a deviation from the value represents the degree of anisotropy of elasticity [32].
A positive value of Cauchy stress (C C )

12 44 indicates the formation of metallic bonds in the alloy system. Cauchy stress is also as a crucial parameter to reflect material's bonding characteristic and intrinsic ductility [33]. The bonding style of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys in the work were judged by Eq. ( 9).

div.head: Phase structure
div.p: Fig. 1 is the experimental and calculated XRD patterns of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys. Firstly, the experimental XRD patterns were identified and the results show that all of these alloys were a single-phase BCC solid solution. Besides, we calculated the theoretical XRD patterns by Powder Diffraction method. As seen in Fig. 1, the calculated data are well agreed with the experimental results. As expected, all of the alloys were singlephase solid solution structure, i.e. BCC structure. Seen in experimental XRD patterns, the peak position of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys shifts to the high 2θ with the decrease of Mo content, indicting the lattice constant decreases after the addition of Mo atom with minimum atomic radius in four elements.

In addition to the XRD patterns' characteristics of the phase structure, the empirical formulas containing valence electron concentration VEC, atomic size difference δ and electronegativity difference Δx are also employed to identify the phase structure of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys. They are interpreted and calculated using the following Eqs. ( 10)- (12).
The valence electron concentration VEC: ,( ,,, )
div.formula: = = = VEC c VEC i Nb Mo Ta W ( )
div.p: In Eq. ( 10), c i and (VEC) i refer to the atomic ratio and valence electron of i th constituent, respectively. The criteria of VEC to predict phase structure are as follows: (a) VEC < 6.87 of BCC structure, (b) VEC > 8 of FCC structure and (c) 6.87 < VEC < 8 of BCC and FCC structure [34].
The atomic size difference δ:
div.formula: = = = = = c r r r c r i Nb Mo Ta W (1 / ¯) , ¯, ( , , , ) i n i i i n i i 1 2 1 (11)
div.p: In Eq. (11), r is the average atomic radius of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys. c i and r i are the atomic ratio and atomic radius of i th component, respectively. Commonly, δ < 6.6% is identified as the formation of single-phase BCC solid solution [35]. δ is also used to analyze the extent of lattice distortion and predict the variations of RHEAs' lattice constants. The electronegativity difference Δx:
div.formula: = = = = = x c x x x c x i Nb Mo Ta W ( ¯) , ¯, ( , , , ) i n i i i n i i 1 2 1 (12)
div.p: In Eq. ( 12), x is the mean Pauling electronegativity of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys. c i and x i are the atomic ratio and the Pauling electronegativity of i th component, respectively. Generally, electronegativity of elements refers to the capacity of atom which gets or lost electron [36]. The larger value of electronegativity of element is, the stronger electron attractor and elements' nonmetallic character are. Otherwise, the stronger ductility and metallic character are. Δx is also used to judge the ductility of elements. Mo and W elements have the larger electronegativity in these alloys (Nb-1.6, Ta-1.5, W-2.36 and Mo-2.16), indicating that Mo and W elements are brittle elements in contrast with the other elements. The electronegativity difference Δx of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys were calculated and drawn in Fig. 2. Unfortunately, the values of four alloys are close with the increase of Mo content. The data of Δx are insufficient to indicate the ductility of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys systems.

The results of valence electron concentration VEC and atomic size difference δ of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys were plotted in Fig. 2. As seen, the values of VEC are less than 6.87, demonstrating that BCC single-phase solid solution structure is formed and existed steady and prior to the other structures. Similarly, all the values of δ are no more than 6.6%, indicating that all alloys are BCC structure. The experimental results are further verified by empirical formulas. Besides, we found that the VEC of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys are basically same. Nevertheless, the values δ of four alloys increase with the increase of Mo content, meaning that the lattice distortion becomes severer after the addition of Mo element.

Lastly, cohesive energy E coh usually used to describe the thermodynamic structural stability of crystal materials based on the calculated ground total energy was proposed. The lower negative E coh shows that alloy system possesses the lager thermodynamic structural stability [37]. Therefore, the E coh of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys were calculated using the following Eq. ( 13): ,, )
div.formula: = = ( ) E N E n E i Nb Mo Ta W 1 , ( ,
coh i tot i atom i (13
div.p: In Eq. ( 13), E tot represents the calculated ground total energy of each alloy. N i is the total atomic numbers in a crystal cell. n i and E atom i are the atomic ratio and the total energy of isolated atom of i th constituent. As seen in Fig. 3, the absolute value of E coh of BCC structure is biggest among three structures, indicating that all the (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys are single-phase BCC structure and existed steady. The results of E coh are well matched with the experimental and calculated XRD patterns, as well as the conclusion analyzed by empirical formulas. Finally, based on the results of experimental and calculated XRD patterns, empirical formulas and cohesive energy, single-phase solid solution with BCC structure of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys are determined and selected in elastic properties' calculation. And BCC structure of these alloys is considered as to be mechanically stable because their elastic constants fit to Eq. ( 7).

div.head: Lattice constant and density
div.p: Lattice constant is the basic structural parameter of crystalline material, which relates to atomic interaction. They reflect atomic position and the status of stress in crystal due to the change of composition. Density is also associated with lattice constant. Therefore, lattice constant and density of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys were calculated and plotted in Fig. 4. As shown, with the decrease Mo content, the same variation of lattice constant and density of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys can be observed. Among four components, their atomic radius and density satisfy the following relationships, Mo (136.3 pm) < W (137.1 pm) < Nb (142.9 pm) < Ta (143 pm) and Nb (8.57 g/cm 3 ) < Mo (10.2 g/cm 3 ) < Ta (16.6 g/cm 3 ) < W (19.3 g/cm 3 ). With the increase of Mo content with the least atomic radius, the mixed atomic radius of alloy system decreases. Similarly, the mixed density of alloy system decreases.

div.head: Microstructures
div.p: Fig. 5 shows the Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) backscatter electron images of the as-cast (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys. As shown in these figures, all of the as-cast alloys are observed to be composed of dendrite structures. The average size of dendrite is relatively uniform. Mo 0 alloy possesses a much finer grain compared with the other alloy in present work. Oppositely, the size of grain in Mo 15 alloy is largest in four alloys. With the increase of Mo content, the grain size first increases (x < 0.15) and then decreases (x > 0.15). According to grain boundary strengthening theory (Hall-Petch strengthening), the strength and ductility of Mo 0 alloy would be superior to that of the other alloys.

Elements distribution of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys were further identified by Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy (EDS) analysis. The EDS results shown in Table 2 demonstrate that there is severe components segregation in these alloys. Among Nb, Mo, Ta and W elements, Ta element distributes uniformly in both dendrite arms and interdendrite regions. Both Nb and Mo elements are gathered in interdendrite region and are poor in dendrite arms. However, the content of W element in dendrite arms is enriched than that in interdendrite regions. The phenomenon can also be observed in SEM mapping images (Fig. 6) of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys. Seen in mapping images of each component, with the increase of Mo content, the increasingly severe segregation of Nb, W and Mo elements are detected during mapping.

div.head: Table 2
div.p: The EDS results of as-cast (NbTaW)

div.head: Mechanical properties
div.p: The room temperature ductility and strength of RHEAs have received the increasing attention. Therefore, the engineering compressive stress-strain curves of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys were measured at room temperature and it was plotted in Fig. 7. The compressive properties of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys were also collected in Table 3. In present work, Mo 0 alloy yielded at σ 0.2 = 1298 MPa, and 8(a). The feathers of fracture surface illustrate that the behavior of fracture of Mo 0 alloy is trans-granular fracture. In Fig. 8(b) and (c), the appearance of a few crack along the grain boundary and grain-like steps show that the behavior of fracture changes from trans-granular fracture to inter-granular fracture and partial cleavage fracture with the content of Mo increasing from x = 0 to x = 0.15. When the content of Mo increases to x = 0.25, the style of fracture completely is characterized by inter-granular fracture (Fig. 8(d)). According to the fractography of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys, the strength and ductility decreases with the increase of Mo content. The above engineering compressive stress-strain curves well demonstrate our analytic results.

div.head: Table 3
div.p: Compressive properties of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys.

div.head: Alloys
div.p: Yield stress σ 0. In order to further study the influence of brittle Mo on the mechanical properties of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys. The elastic constants (C 11 , C 12 , C 44 ) and polycrystalline elastic modulus (B, G, E, ν) were calculated by VCA method and Voigt-Reuss-Hill (VRH) approximate methods. The data were gathered in Table 4.

To compare their mechanical properties conveniently, the elastic constant (C 11 , C 12 , C 44 ) and polycrystalline elastic modulus (B, G, E) of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys were plotted in Fig. 9. As seen, the variations of C 12 and B were of coincidence. The values of (C 11 , C 44 ) and polycrystalline elastic modulus (G, E) rose with the increase of Mo content. Elastic constants (C 11 , C 12 , C 44 ) are positively correlated with polycrystalline elastic modulus (B, G, E), which fits to the regularity shown in Fig. 9. Commonly, bulk modulus B is known as the expression of materials' incompressibility and ductility. The larger value of B is, the larger incompressibility is, and the worse ductility is. Similarly, shear modulus G is the reflection of the ability of a material to resist shear deformation. The larger the shear modulus is, the better the stiffness of the material is, and the worse ductility is. The basically same values of B show that four alloys have similar incompressibility. The values of G increase with the increase of Mo content, indicating that the ability of resisting shear deformation improves and the ductility weaken. Besides, NbTaW MEA has the minimum value of B and G, meaning that it possesses the strongest compressibility, deformability and ductility compared with quaternary RHEAs. This coincides with the experimental data.

Yong's modulus (E) can be regarded as an index to measure the difficulty of elastic deformation of materials. The greater the value is, the greater the stress that causes certain elastic deformation of materials is. That is to say, the stiffness of materials is greater.

Besides, E has anisotropy of elasticity, which leads to diverse properties in different directions. Thus, Yong's modulus E of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys were calculated based on the elastic constants (C 11 , C 12 , C 44 ). The three-dimensional diagrams of Yong's modulus (E) were plotted in Fig. 10. From the results we can see that the obvious elastic anisotropy for (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys. The stiffness of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys increases with the increases Mo content. It is observed that the elastic anisotropy of E fits to the following orders: Mo 25 < Mo 15 < Mo 5 < Mo 0 .

Besides, elastic anisotropy of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys were calculated by Eq. ( 8) and the results were gathered in Table 4. A VR = 0 shows elastic isotropy of materials. As seen in Table 4, all the calculated A VR were large than zero, indicating that all alloys in present work are elastic anisotropy. The degree of anisotropy evaluated by formula are similar to the threedimensional diagrams of E. A VR = 0.280 of Mo 25 shows the uniformly properties in different directions. Contrast to Mo 25 RHEA, A VR = 0.380 of Mo 0 alloy have various orientation performance.

The value of B/G and ν are usually used to predict materials' ductility/brittleness. Therefore, B/G and ν of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys were calculated according to elastic modulus. If B/G > 1.75, it is identified as ductile material. Otherwise, the material shows a brittle fracture behavior. Poisson's ratio (ν > 0.33) is defined as ductile material. ν < 0.33 represents brittle material. The calculated B/G and ν were collected in Table 4 and plotted in Fig. 11. As seen, Fig. 11 obviously illustrates the relationship of ductile in four alloys. Both B/ G and ν have the same variation. The values of B/G and ν decrease with the increase of Mo content, demonstrating that ductility of these alloys weaken. Mo 0 MEA has the maximal ductility among four alloys, which is well agreed with the mechanical properties analyzed by compressive stress-strain curves and elastic modulus, as well as the microstructure. Another significant criteria is Cauchy stress (C 12 -C 44 ). A positive value of (C 12 -C 44 ) stands for the formation of metallic bonds and materials show intrinsic ductility. As seen in Table 4, all the value of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys are positive, indicating that the alloy combines with metallic bonds and shows ductility.

div.head: Microhardness
div.p: Microhardness is concerned to materials' ductility and strength. Thus, we measured the microhardness (HV) of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys using Vickers hardness tester. The testing of ten randomly selected locations was carried out in the loading conditions of 100 g and 15 s. Besides, the theoretical microhardness of these RHEAs was predicted using Eq. ( 14), which was usually employed to predict materials' microhardness.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys were prepared by arc melted method. The evolution of microstructure and common mechanical properties were characterized and the main issues are highlighted as follows:

(a) The results of experimental and theoretical XRD patterns, empirical formulas, as well as cohesive energy show that (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys are BCC single-phase solid solution. The peak position shifts to the high 2θ with the increase of Mo content. The Mo content dependence of both lattice constant and density were predicted and analyzed. With the increase of Mo content, lattice constant and density decrease.

(b) Microstructure and elements distribution were characterized by SEM and EDS. The result shows that all of the as-cast alloys are composed of dendrite structures and the grain size first increases (x < 0.15) and then decreases (x > 0.15) with the increase of Mo content. Ta element distributes uniformly in both dendrite arms and interdendrite regions. Both Nb and Mo elements are gathered in interdendrite region and are poor in dendrite arms. The content of W element in dendrite arms is enriched than that in interdendrite regions.

(c) The engineering compressive stress-strain curves of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys were measured at room temperature. The results show that Mo 0 alloy has the largest strength (1460 MPa) and ductility (16.2%) compared with the other alloys. Mo 5 , Mo 15 and Mo 25 alloys have similar compressive mechanical properties. The mechanical properties of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15) alloys are enhanced compared with Mo 25 alloy, which resulted from the grain boundary strengthening and solid solution strengthening. The compressive experiments evidences that adjusting the content of brittle Mo element in (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys can effectively improve their mechanical properties. Similarly, the SEM secondary electron images of fracture surfaces of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys show the strength and ductility decrease with the increase of Mo content.

(d) The elastic properties of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys were calculated. The elastic constant and modulus increase with the increase of Mo content, showing the mechanical properties of these alloys enhances. The B/G, ν and (C 12 -C 44 ) indicate the ductility decreases with the increase of Mo content. The order of elastic anisotropy are (NbTaW) 0.75 Mo 0.25 < (NbTaW) 0.85 Mo 0.15 < (NbTaW) 0.95 Mo 0.05 < NbTaW. The microhardness increases with the increase of Mo content from the perspective of experiments and theories.

div.head: CRediT authorship contribution statement
div.p: Yonggang Tong, Linhui Bai, Xiubing Liang and Yongle Hu, contributed the central idea, analyzed most of the data, and wrote the initial draft of the paper. The remaining authors contributed to refining the ideas, carrying out additional analyses and finalizing this paper.

div.head: Declaration of Competing Interest
div.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 2. The valence electron concentration VEC and atomic size difference δ of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 3. The cohesive energy of different structures of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 4. Calculated lattice constant and density of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 6. Energy Dispersive Spectroscopy mapping of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys: (a) NbTaW, (b) (NbTaW) 0.95 Mo 0.05 , (c) (NbTaW) 0.85 Mo 0.15 and (d) (NbTaW) 0.75 Mo 0.25 .

figure.head: Fig. 7 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 7. The engineering compressive stress-strain curves of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys.

figure.head: Fig. 8 .
figure.figDesc: Fig. 8. SEM secondary electron images of fracture surfaces of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys: (a) NbTaW, (b) (NbTaW) 0.95 Mo 0.05 , (c) (NbTaW) 0.85 Mo 0.15 and (d) (NbTaW) 0.75 Mo 0.25 .

and B are the calculated shear and bulk modulus. The values of microhardness were plotted in Fig.12. The average HV are respectively measured to be 4023 MPa for Mo 0 alloy, 5573 MPa for Mo 5 alloy, 7684 MPa for Mo 15 alloy and 7633 MPa for Mo 25 alloy by experiments. The calculated hardness of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x alloys are 5227 MPa, 5696 MPa, 6158 MPa and 6300 MPa, respectively. As seen in Fig.12, the experimental hardness is well consistent with the calculated data. Hardness of Mo 0 MEA is lowest in four alloys. The hardness increases with the increase of Mo content. This coincides with the analysis of elastic modulus and the above criteria.

figure.figDesc: Fig. 12. The predicted and experimental hardness of (NbTaW) 1-x Mo x (x = 0, 0.05, 0.15, 0.25) alloys.
